Brothers Four To Spark University Prom
Cotillion Board Sees
'Best Proin Ever'
The Cotillion Board has announced that the Johns
Hopkins University Prom will be held this year at the
Fifth Regiment Armory on the night of March 10. It will
run from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M.
The theme as described by Co-chairmen Joe Perrot°,
Pete Tenter, and John Wetzig will be "Carousel." Featured at the dance will be The Brothers Four and Billy
Butterfield's orchestra with Dotty Smith as vocalist.
The Cotillion Board emphasizes that should this
dance be a success, they will sponsor a big spring weekend
the following year. The dance will be open to all undergraduates, faculty, administration, grad students, employees, and students of McCoy College. The board is
hoping for a turnout of about 1500 couples. A substantially smaller number than this will definitely dampen the
plans for the Spring weekend next year.
There will be a faculty greeting line at the entrance,
an attempt to improve faculty-student relations on a
social basis.
Favors for the dance will be small parasols made
from women's handkerchiefs. Decorations will include
a carousel in the middle of the armory and gigantic translucent tubes rising from the floor to the lights on the
ceiling. The dance will be informal.
The co-ordination of reservations of tables and
chairs for groups will be handled by one organization;
which one will be announced later. It is hoped that this
will avoid confusion. Set-ups will be sold at refreshment
booths.
Tickets will be sold by members of the D.S.R.C.,
Cotillion Board, II-Club and Booster Club.

By PHIL EHRENSAFT and BOB REINHOLD
Hopkins freshman Andrew Miller of New Rochelle, New York,
was one of twenty-two sit-in demonstrators arrested at Baltimore

several others at the White Coffee Pot resturant at Baltimore and
St. Paul Streets when he refused to leave after having been read

segregation in the whole state ends. In reaction to the mass sit-ins,
the Maryland Restaurant Association, an organization of major
restaurant owners, is considering the removal of its support for
equal accommodations legislation in the Maryland legislature.

nominee for Congress in the Fourth District, was among those
jailed. He described the demonstration as "eminently successful."

A Pat On Our Back
The News-Letter's stand against racial injustices in
the city of Baltimore has been and still is quite clear and
unequivocal. We do not feel if necessary to restate our
position at this time. We do, however, wish to take this
opportunity to gloat at the resounding success of the
militant sit-in movement in Baltimore and America and
the part we have played in it.
Students of the Johns Hopkins University have been
given credit by the Baltimore Urban League for initiating
the Baltimore integration movement. It was two years
ago in February that the first sit-in in Baltimore, initiated
primarily by white students, was incubated. The NewsLetter had revealed to a largely ignorant campus the
facts of the appalling conditions of racial intolerance
toward both Negroes and foreign students in Homewood's
surrounding neighborhood. Shortly afterward a somewhat weak and disorganized sit-in was held at the BlueJay Restaurant. It was bound to fail, but it accomplished
one important objective. The relatively docile Baltimore
Negro community was shamed into action. Quite soon
the Civic Interest Group became extremely active and
began to steamroll through racial barriers that have
stood for decades.
In less than two years since that sit-in, Baltimore's
Negro community has acquired more of the rights and
dignity due to first-class American citizens than they have
in decades of indifference. The difference is striking to
even the most casual observer.
The events of the last week convince us beyond
doubt of the efficacy of the sit-in movement and passive
resistance. We refer to the now internationally infamous
U.S. Route 40. Urgent desegregation pleas by the United
States Department of State to some eighty restaurants
along this well travelled route went all but unheeded.
However, the mere threat of hundreds of Freedom Riders
invading their establishments was enough to induce
thirty-five proprietors to open their services to all persons. Without doubt the passive resistance movement
strikes fear in the hearts of people imbued with the
antiquated and outdated traditions of their forefathers.
Too fast? Nonsense, we submit. If one regards
the rapid decline of American prestige abroad in today's
world of dynamic change, then there is no such thing as
going "too fast" in this area.
Despite the harsh criticism leveled at the News-Letter
for "instigating" action of this sort, we remain proud of
the minor, but still significant role we have played in
this vital and changing time.

Stop and Think
The apparent conflict between the DSRC and the
SC over the question of judicial systems seems to be based
more on misunderstanding than any real disagreement.
The DSRC,recognizing the need for a revision of its
judicial processes, has proceeded to set up the plans for
a new judicial board within the dormitories. The SC in
a parallel action has begun a constitutional revision which
includes the establishment of a non-academic judicial
board.
The position of the DSRC in respect to the Student
Council's action is quite simple. It is moving forward
with its plans and will establish a new judicial board
which will function until superseded by a larger group
established by the SC. Until this campus-wide judicial
board begins operation, which will probably not be until
next year, the DSRC will have the benefits of its new
judicial process.
It is quite apparent that if the DSRC heeds the Student Council demand to stop its plans, it will have to use
its admittedly defective judicial system for a full year.
This would be a grave injustice to the dormitory residents.
Therefore, we urge the Student Council to rescind its
misguided instructions to the DSRC and avoid needless
controversy which will serve no purpose and create no
good.

A Pat On Our Back
The News-Letter's stand against racial injustices in
the city of Baltimore has been and still is quite clear and
unequivocal. We do not feel if necessary to restate our
position at this time. We do, however, wish to take this
opportunity to gloat at the resounding success of the
militant sit-in movement in Baltimore and America and
the part we have played in it.
Students of the Johns Hopkins University have been
given credit by the Baltimore Urban League for initiating
the Baltimore integration movement. It was two years
ago in February that the first sit-in in Baltimore, initiated
primarily by white students, was incubated. The NewsLetter had revealed to a largely ignorant campus the
facts of the appalling conditions of racial intolerance
toward both Negroes and foreign students in Homewood's
surrounding neighborhood. Shortly afterward a somewhat weak and disorganized sit-in was held at the BlueJay Restaurant. It was bound to fail, but it accomplished
one important objective. The relatively docile Baltimore
Negro community was shamed into action. Quite soon
the Civic Interest Group became extremely active and
began to steamroll through racial barriers that have
stood for decades.
In less than two years since that sit-in, Baltimore's
Negro community has acquired more of the rights and
dignity due to first-class American citizens than they have
in decades of indifference. The difference is striking to
